Tear gas and flash bangs in Ferguson
12:15 a.m. ET: Police finally cracked down on the protests just after 11 p.m. local time, launching a barrage of smoke bombs, tear gas and flash bangs at a crowd.
The action came after police on a megaphone repeatedly warned protesters to get out of the QuikTrip area -- a spot that's been deemed off limits. Vice News's Tim Pool said on his livestream that the protesters had thrown items into the street.
Reporters and protesters alike scrambled for cover of a thick, acrid smoke filled the air and soon, as police moved from smoke bombs to tear gas, their lungs.
[tweetbegin 501584131235799040 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501585365577527297 tweetend]
There were reports of gunshots in the area. Reporters on the ground and viewers of the numerous livestreams reported hearing five to six shots fired in succession, though it wasn't immediately clear if they were real bullets or the police firing rubber bullets on a crowd.
[tweetbegin 501583865828638720 tweetend]
Pool described hearing "live ammunition shots" as journalists gathered near him hit the ground. Then, they ran. Later, speaking to a police officer clearing the area, Pool confirmed they were live shots. "The bad guys fired," not the police, the officer said. 
[tweetbegin 501584993865723904 tweetend]
Missouri Gov. says he spoke with Obama about efforts to "restore peace," draws criticism for tweets
12:09 a.m. ET: Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon tweeted late Monday that he spoke with U.S. President Barack Obama about efforts to "restore peace and achieve justice" in Ferguson.
[tweetbegin 501576972934594560 tweetend]
Nixon also encouraged demonstrators to "protest peacefully and passionately."
[tweetbegin 501579772778926080 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501574825018523648 tweetend]
Reaction to Nixon's tweets were largely negative, with some Twitter users criticizing the governor for what they perceive to be excessive police force in Ferguson. – AL
CNN anchor on police response: "This doesn't make any sense"
11:45 p.m. ET: As the protests in Ferguson draw international attention, they are also drawing a heavy media presence, exposing raw emotion and tense standoffs on live television.On CNN, anchor Jake Tapper was positioned to the side of the police cordon, while toting a gas mask, as he watched the scene unfold. Protesters dispersed, as the assembled law enforcement officials drew semiautomatic weapons.Noting that protesters had perhaps thrown a few water bottles, but nothing more, Tapper said he couldn't understand the disproportionate police response. "What is this?" he said, in the perplexed tones of a reporter willing to drop a bit of objectivity. "This doesn't make any sense."
[tweetbegin 501567006517522433 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501565948940529664 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501567019146559488 tweetend]
Tapper didn't need to use his gas mask, and the standoff eventually dissipated.
On MSNBC, Chris Hayes was farther away from protesters and the police, standing in a gated lot. But at one point during his broadcast, he was pelted with stones, their source unclear.
[tweetbegin 501567322427899904 tweetend]
“There's some rocks headed in our direction at the moment," Hayes said.
At least one of the stones hit him, but he appeared uninjured and continued his broadcast. – JE
Captain Johnson at the front lines
11:20 p.m. ET: Missouri State Highway Patrol Captain Ronald S. Johnson was spotted at the front lines just as the conflict seemed ready to boil over.
[tweetbegin 501568979761364993 tweetend]
He walked out to meet a protest leader dressed only in his uniform -- no jacket, gas mask or helmet.
[tweetbegin 501569149613932544 tweetend]
The police stepped back, the protesters backed down and a brief round of applause broke out on W. Florissant. – BR
Protesters, police face off in Ferguson
FERGUSON, Mo., 11 p.m. ET: The heavy artillery is out, including four SWAT vehicles. Police are telling every person to disperse. People are panicking. A very loud Long Range Acoustic Device (LRAD) is making the scene very chaotic at Ferguson and Florissant.
[tweetbegin 501562201095024641 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501563892028694528 tweetend]
The police vehicle is driving up the road trying to disperse the crowd -- but no protester was causing a ruckus. The only thing that happened was when police start making a wall at the end of the street, some in the crowd began throwing water bottles.
Police then came on the loudspeaker, and told people to disperse, and for the media to get out of the way. - AW
Schools in Ferguson will be closed for the remainder of the week
10:42 p.m. ET: Schools in the Ferguson-Florissant School District will be closed from Tuesday through Friday due to the unrest in the area, the district announced late Monday.
"We believe that closing schools for the rest of this week will allow needed time for peace and stability to be restored to our community," the district said in an update to its {website}<hyperlink” http://www.fergflor.org/pages/Ferguson-Florissant_SD”>. "This decision was made after much careful deliberation and consideration of input received from local law enforcement officials and District security staff."
Due to the delay, the first day of school in the district will be on Monday, Aug. 25.
In a letter to parents from Lawrence W. Larrew, acting superintendent of the Ferguson-Florissant School District, said the district is reviewing security at each of its schools, and is coordinating grief counseling to support students. – AL
Trayvon Martin's mother writes open letter to Brown family
10:14 p.m. ET: The mother of Trayvon Martin wrote an open letter to Michael Brown's family, which was published Monday night."I hate that you and your family must join this exclusive yet growing group of parents and relatives who have lost loved ones to senseless gun violence," Sybrina Fulton wrote in a piece {published by Time magazine}<hyperlink=”https://storify.com/”>. "Further complicating the pain and loss in this tragedy is the fact that the killer of your son is alive, known and currently free."In her letter addressed to "the Brown family," Fulton encourages them to find a support network in light of the "myths and flat-out lies" regarding Michael Brown's case, and to "fight injustice.""If they refuse to hear us, we will make them feel us," she wrote.Fulton is the founder of the Trayvon Martin Foundation, which aims to support families of victims of violent crime. Read Fulton's entire letter, {here}<hyperlink=”http://time.com/3136685/travyon-sybrina-fulton-ferguson/”>. – AL
Ferguson prepares for another long night
FERGUSON, Missouri, 9:56 p.m. ET: It's dark in Ferguson, and there's now a helicopter buzzing overhead, shining a bright white light across the block.
For Ruth Gordon, who's nearly 73 years old and has been marching every evening since Brown was killed, it's time to go home. Another Ferguson resident, Denise Little, helps Gordon, who is wearing a handicap sign in a makeshift necklace around her neck, cross the street. "When the sun goes down, we go home," Gordon says. "That's when things start changing."
[tweetbegin 501542961990336512 tweetend]
Just minutes after she walks out of sight, the helicopter above sinks lower, its spotlight becoming brighter and more visible. The crowds are starting to get louder and closer together. Parents start putting face masks on their children.
[tweetbegin 501550497233657856 tweetend]
Ferguson is preparing for another long night. - AW
Ferguson marches on while police guard McDonald's
FERGUSON, Missouri, 9:02 p.m. ET -- As the sun sets in ferguson, the intersection of Florissant Avenue and Ferguson Avenue are filled with peaceful protesters, who police are telling to keep moving around in a circle to avoid "clusters" that could result in violence.
However, the McDonalds restaurant on this corner, which has become the epicenter of these protests, is guarded by police in bulletproof vests, who stand in its empty parking lot.
A local policeman with the St. Louis metropolitan police told Mashable that "someone from McDonald's corporate" flew in this morning and shut down the restaurant.
No word on when it will reopen. – AW
Protesters walk with '1000 roses' for Michael Brown
8:31 p.m. ET: At Monday night's demonstration in Ferguson, protesters carried red roses in remembrance of Michael Brown, whose death at the hands of a police officer ignited the unrest in the St. Louis suburb.
Police have {been arresting}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/jmachetta/status/501518951344783360”> demonstrators who stop moving, so the group marches in circles up and down the sidewalks of Florissant Avenue.
[tweetbegin 501513314468651009 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501515679804448768 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501521623569006593 tweetend]
The arrival of rapper and St. Louis native Nelly, wearing a {#MikeBrown T-shirt}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/ryanjreilly/status/501527261599006721”> in solidarity with the Ferguson community, caused a media scrum. Demonstrations, however, remained peaceful, with people handing out bottled water and barbecue to those who marched. – KSD
[tweetbegin 501530056590884865 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501537640706215938 tweetend]
The National Guard arrives
7:30 p.m. ET: The Missouri National Guard has arrived in Ferguson.
Reporters at the police staging area reported seeing a number of humvees roll in just after 6 p.m. local time.
[tweetbegin 501510390149578753 tweetend]
The Guard was summoned by Missouri Governor Jay Nixon and given a "limited" role, tasked with keeping the central command area safe and secure. President Obama said on Monday he would be monitoring to assure their role doesn't extend beyond that scope. – BR
Getty Images photographer arrested in Ferguson
6:44 p.m. ET: As it has every night since Michael Brown was shot, unrest is beginning to escalate in Ferguson as evening falls, this time with the arrest of multiple protesters, including at least one journalist.
Multiple images on Twitter and Instagram show that a Getty Images photographer, Scott Olson, has been arrested. Telegraph correspondent {Rob Crilly tweeted},hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/robcrilly/status/501498257244049409”> Olson was arrested for "not getting out of the way fast enough when ordered."
[tweetbegin 501497010189791232 tweetend]
Update, 9:12 p.m. ET: Getty Images released a statement on the arrest of its photographer Scott Olson:
“Getty Images staff photographer Scott Olson was arrested this afternoon in Ferguson, Missouri, while on assignment documenting the events there. We at Getty Images stand firmly behind our colleague Scott Olson and the right to report from Ferguson. Getty Images is working to secure his release as soon as possible.
"We strongly object to his arrest and are committed to ensuring he is able to resume his important work of capturing some of the most iconic images of this news story." — Pancho Bernasconi, VP, News, Getty Images
CNN's Don Lemon was threatened with arrest during a live report from Ferguson, expressing confusion on-air about why police were forcibly trying to remove him and other protesters.
"We have been here all day, they moved us here and told us this is our location," he says in the video above, before wondering how police are treating demonstrators who don't "have a voice" on national television.
Images of Hedy Epstein, a 90-year-old Holocaust survivor and pro-Palestine activist, being led away from the protest at the Wainwright State Building in handcuffs are also circulating widely. According to her website, Epstein is a St. Louis resident who escaped Germany in 1939 and is the only surviving member of her family. – KSD
Protests spread to St. Louis; police set up "organized protest zone" in Ferguson
5:45 p.m. ET: Demonstrators are marching on a government building in downtown St. Louis -- while the police in Ferguson prepare for another night of protests.
Protesters marched on the Wainwright State Building in downtown St. Louis hoping to find the governor there, local media reported Monday afternoon. Security guards struggled to keep them out -- before the demonstrators began a sit-in outside the building's doors.
[tweetbegin 501474294258757633 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501474833361010689 tweetend]
Back in Ferguson, authorities announced the creation of an "organized protest zone" down the city's main thoroughfare, W. Florissant Ave, that's seen the majority of the action these past few nights. Members of the media were invited to stay in a previous staging area or set up at a new one located directly across the street from the new protest zone.
[tweetbegin 501478490479132672 tweetend]
Speaking at a press conference earlier in the afternoon, Missouri Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald S. Johnson said peaceful demonstrations would be welcome -- on the first night since Friday without a curfew -- but police wouldn't allow any troublemakers.
"We will not allow vandals, criminal elements to impact the safety and security of this community," he said. "We will not allow those elements disrupt, impact, the soul of this community."
By 5 p.m. local time, police began shutting down roads around the area and checking identification of people in the area. – BR
Obama: "Let’s seek to heal rather than to wound each other"
4:45 p.m. ET: Attorney General Eric Holder is headed to Ferguson on Wednesday to meet with FBI agents and Department of Justice personnel conducting an independent investigation into Michael Brown's death, President Barack Obama said on Monday afternoon. Holder will also meet with other leaders in the community "whose support is so critical to bringing about peace and calm in Ferguson," Obama said, adding that Ronald Davis, the director of the DOJ’s Office of Community Oriented Policing Services, is headed there as well to work with police officials on the ground.
Obama then spoke of the "tensions" that have crippled Ferguson for the past week.
"While I understand the passions and the anger that arise over the death of Michael Brown, giving into that anger by looting or carrying guns, and even attacking the police only serves to raise tensions and stir chaos," he said. "It undermines rather than advancing justice."
He also called for the guarantee of "constitutional rights" on the ground, including the rights to speak freely, to assemble and to report in the press. These "must be vigilantly safeguarded," Obama said. "There’s no excuse for excessive force by police or any action that denies people the right to protest peacefully."
"Ours is a nation of laws," Obama concluded, "of citizens who live under them and for the citizens who enforce them. So, to a community in Ferguson that is rightly hurting and looking for answers, let me call once again for us to seek some understanding rather than simply holler at each other."
"Let’s seek to heal rather than to wound each other." – BR
Marijuana found in Brown's system, report says
3:45 p.m. ET: The Washington Post is reporting, {citing an anonymous source}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/08/18/county-investigation-michael-brown-was-shot-from-the-front-had-marijuana-in-his-system/”>, that Michael Brown "had marijuana in his system" when he was shot by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson.The source reportedly saw an autopsy report from Mary Case, the St. Louis County medical examiner, which was provided to the St. Louis County prosecutor’s office (but not released to the public).Reached by Mashable, Case was unable to confirm or deny the report, stating she could only remark on "cause and manner of death." We've asked for more information.This is at least the second time an official has brought Brown's actions before the shooting into question. On Friday, Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson released video that reportedly showed Brown stealing a box of cigarillos from a local liquor store.The Brown family's attorneys questioned the motives behind that release, calling it a "strategic" move and an "assassination" of the unarmed teenager's character.
Gov. Jay Nixon {criticized}<hyperlink” http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/17/jay-nixon-michael-brown_n_5685775.html”> that move in appearances on Sunday talk shows.
"We certainly were not happy with that being released, especially in the way that it was," Nixon said on ABC's This Week with George Stephanopoulos. "It appeared to cast aspersions on a young man that was gunned down in the street. It made emotions raw."
"To attempt to in essence disparage the character of this victim in the middle of a process is not right. It’s just not right," he later said on NBC's Meet the Press. "And secondarily, it did put the community, and quite frankly the region and the nation, on alert again. These are old wounds. These are deep wounds in these communities. And that action was not helpful." – BR
Governor lifts curfew in Ferguson, says National Guard mission is "limited"
1:50 p.m. ET: Missouri Governor Jay Nixon issued a statement on Monday afternoon that clarified the role the National Guard will play in Ferguson, and announced that the curfew will be lifted. The curfew had been instituted on Saturday night when Gov. Nixon announced a state of emergency due to the ongoing protests. It went into effect at midnight on Saturday and Sunday nights.
In his statement, Gov. Nixon said the National Guard's role would be "limited," noting it was there "to provide protection, and ensure the safety of our Unified Command Center," which was the target last night of a coordinated attack. The guard will concentrate its resources on carrying out this limited mission."
"We are all frustrated and looking for justice to be achieved regarding the shooting death of Michael Brown," the governor said. "As the dual investigations continue into what happened nine days ago at Canfield Green, we must defend Ferguson from these violent interlopers so that the peaceful protests can operate in peace and the search for answers and justice can continue." - BR
See the full statement:
Michael Brown's mother calls for arrest of officer who shot her son
12:45 p.m. ET: Michael Brown's mother, Lesley McSpadden, called for the arrest of Darren Wilson, the officer who shot her son, in an {appearance}<hyperlink=”http://www.abc15.com/news/national/michael-browns-mother-lesley-mcspadden-speaks-out-to-abc?autoplay=true”> on Good Morning America on Monday.
Asked by GMA's Robin Roberts what would bring peace to Ferguson, McSpadden answered had one answer: "Justice."
”Being fair; arresting this man and making him accountable for his actions,” she said.
“It confirms our worst fears that the witnesses were telling the truth,” her attorney, Benjamin Crump added. “The most troubling was the head shot. It’s just not justified in any way fashion or form to execute this child.” - BR
{Watch the clip}<hyperlink=”http://www.abc15.com/news/national/michael-browns-mother-lesley-mcspadden-speaks-out-to-abc?autoplay=true”>.
Brown family attorneys address autopsy report
11 a.m. ET: Michael Brown did not suffer when he was fatally wounded in his encounter with Ferguson police, an attorney for the 18-year-old's family said Monday morning.
The attorneys held a press conference to address the findings of a preliminary autopsy report.
That autopsy revealed, attorneys said, that Michael Brown was shot at least six times, with the "kill shot" entering Brown's head at its apex. That caused an immediate loss of consciousness, said Dr. Michael Baden, a pathologist who performed a private autopsy for Brown's family.
"We believe that given those kinds of facts, this officer should have been arrested," said attorney Daryl Parks.
[tweetbegin 501382089498185728 tweetend]
Shawn Parcells, a forensic pathologist who worked with Baden on the autopsy, explained how two of the bullets may have exited and re-entered Brown's body. One bullet, he said, may have entered, exited, entered and exited again.
They are consistent with Brown moving either toward or away from the officer at the time he was shot. Pathologists couldn't say whether Brown was attacking the officer, surrendering with his hands up or defending himself.
[tweetbegin 501384392556949505 tweetend]
Baden added that there were no signs of a struggle. Brown's face had some abrasions on it, he said, but they were likely caused by its impact with the ground after he was shot.
He took one question from a member of the public, who asked if the wounds were survivable. "All of these gunshots wounds were survivable -- except for the one on top of the head," Dr. Baden said.
"Then why hasn't this officer been arrested?" the woman asked.
That, for better or for worse, is not a question of forensic science, Baden answered.
That's a question that residents of Ferguson, the St. Louis suburb that's been at the center of protests this week, want to know. Some of them were "glued" to the news conference, watching on a TV at the local McDonald's, as captured by Los Angeles Times reporter Matt Pearce. - BR
[tweetbegin 501386833855397889 tweetend]
Missouri governor sends National Guard to Ferguson
10:30 a.m. ET: Missouri's governor on Monday ordered the National Guard to a St. Louis suburb {convulsed by protests}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/17/hours-before-the-curfew-protesters-clash-with-police-in-ferguson/#PsYfVHOz4kqY”> over the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teen, after a night in which police used tear gas to clear protesters off the streets well ahead of a curfew.
Gov. Jay Nixon said the National Guard would help "in restoring peace and order" to Ferguson, where protests over the killing of 18-year-old Michael Brown by a white police officer entered their second week. Police said they acted in response to gunfire, looting, vandalism and protesters who hurled Molotov cocktails.
[tweetbegin 501179623275642880 tweetend]
"These violent acts are a disservice to the family of Michael Brown and his memory and to the people of this community who yearn for justice to be served and to feel safe in their own homes," Nixon {said in a statement}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/18/missouri-governor-sends-national-guard-to-ferguson/#tC.iQae6Ruqt”>.

Title: Ferguson Protester: 'You Don't Want to Be Here After Sundown'
Author: Amanda Wills
ArticleText:
FERGUSON, Missouri — “It’s time to go home,” Ruth Gordon said, looking up into the petal pink sky that was giving way to dark blue as nighttime started to fall here.
“You don’t want to be here after sundown,” she added.
Like many people in Ferguson, Gordon has been on this stretch of road near the intersection of Ferguson Avenue and West Florissant Avenue every day of these protests. However, unlike most people in this crowd of hundreds, Gordon is nearing 73 years of age.
With a handicap hangtag tied around her neck in a makeshift necklace, Gordon can barely walk without the help of Ferguson resident Denise Little. As the two made their way down the main drag, hand in hand, they could have easily passed for close family or dearest of friends. But when I asked if Gordon was Little’s mother, they both smiled warmly.
“We just met,” Little said. “She looked like she needed help.”
[tweetbegin 501542961990336512 tweetend]
In the hours dwindling down to sunset, Florissant Avenue is filled with people like this. They come from all corners of St. Louis — from around the corner in Ferguson, to the south end of the city — to peacefully protest the shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown.
Children carry hand-drawn pictures; others chant while holding their hands in the air. A few volunteers from local churches hand out much-needed bottles of water. The demonstrators stay on sidewalks. They say prayers with one another. Some even tell police officers here to have a nice evening, to which the officers nod their heads and genuinely smile in return.
However, as Gordon and Little note, things look “very different” on Florissant Avenue when the sun goes down.
Within the span of an hour or so, the older demonstrators return home as a helicopter circles low overhead, shining a bright spotlight across the asphalt. Many of the people left are younger — some in their 20s, carrying children of their own. The protesters start to grow more wary of their surroundings.
Even the slightest of movements by a police officer jars them. They look over their shoulders while giving interviews in front of the dozens of television cameras pushed in their faces. They put paper masks over their children’s faces to protect them from what’s to come.
But most of all, they are angry. They are defensive. Many of them say they feel marginalized.
One 21-year-old man, who refused to give his name, said he asked an officer earlier in the evening what he tells his kids about Ferguson when he gets home at night. He said the officer laughed at him.
“This man laughed in my face like this is a joke,” he said.
“A young man lost his life. Is that a joke?”
Another girl, 15, stood at the corner of the intersection with two friends. Even though they had school the next morning, they were out here tonight just like every other. “Are you scared?” I asked, to which the girl nodded before saying, “Yes. It’s crazy out here.” The three teenagers also said Brown and the protests were all they could talk about in the school hallways. It consumes the community. (Schools in the Ferguson-Florissant School District itself will stay closed this week.)
'Be careful out here'
After a violent Sunday night in Ferguson, tensions ran deep on a humid Monday evening.
“Just give it about 15 minutes or so,” one woman said as she made her way home. “Be careful out here,” she warned.
Crowds moved past the torched QuikTrip station and headed to the top of the hill near a McDonald’s, where they have been gathering for days. However, the restaurant closed on Monday morning after “someone from corporate came in,” a police officer told Mashable. Now, the protesters shuffled into a large crowd in the middle of the south side of the intersection.
Outspoken leaders carrying megaphones became the unofficial spokesmen for the crowd. One was wearing prisoner garb, while another man was dressed in a fake cop uniform with a hat that read “murder police.” They shouted on behalf of the protesters and also shouted instructions at them, telling them to remain calm while demanding they keep moving, per police orders.
Then, right on schedule, the entire crowd gasped and many screamed — this time it wasn’t a chant, but rather out of true terror — “Don’t shoot!”
Just over the hill at Ferguson Avenue rolled in armored police tanks, and officers with shields formed a column in front in a standoff. As a few angry protesters threw a couple of water bottles in the direction of the police, the officers slid on their gas masks, and an ear-splitting alarm sounded through the streets. A voice came over a loudspeaker, demanding the protesters disperse.
It was chaos for a half hour as people who were wearing T-shirts that said "peacekeepers" struggled to keep protesters — and members of the press — on the sidewalk. Then, a loud pop rang out from the other end of the street near QuikTrip. As tear gas rose through the air, a crowd that had been milling around at the other end of Florissant Avenue started running toward the intersection where the bigger group was still standing.
Some fell in front of the media tents, scratching at their burning eyes. Members of Amnesty International, most of whom arrived in Ferguson on Monday to assist demonstrators, helped wash out their eyes and get them back on their feet. Other protesters carried spray bottles of milk and Mylanta, offering it to those who were caught in the gas.
[tweetbegin 501584131235799040 tweetend]
'What's the point?'
By this time, most members of the press had moved behind police barricades and into a parking lot that was unofficially deemed a safe zone. Some were packing it up because it seemed as though the the tear gas had thinned out the crowd. The street was completely empty.
It was relatively peaceful here until an armored car sped into the street and slammed its brakes in front of the media. The doors flew open, and at least a half dozen armed guards jumped out of the truck and stood, looking at everyone in a silent warning.
“Is this necessary?” One of the peacekeepers, who was now behind the press barricade with some other demonstrators who were seeking refuge there as well, shouted through this megaphone. “What’s the point?”
And perhaps those words perfectly sum up Monday evening in Ferguson. The sudden and drastic change in attitude of the police seemed unprovoked. It felt as though they were almost toying with the protesters, sending in tanks and speeding up and down the main street in SUVs. It was all pointless.
Although the curfew had been lifted, police still seemed eager to clear out the entire area by midnight, repeatedly threatening to arrest people who weren’t on sidewalks or were carrying signs and not moving enough around the area. When the sting of tear gas rolled in through the entire area, including the media center, it choked those caught off-guard, sending hundreds running in panic.
By 2 a.m., {at least 31 people had been arrested}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/18/ferguson-live-updates/#N3ozbhLfPaqc”>, said Capt. Ron Johnson of the Missouri Highway Patrol. He blamed "violent agitators" and "criminals" for shooting at least two people in the area and throwing Molotov cocktails. The police did not fire bullets, he said.
Johnson urged protesters to demonstrate during the day and stay clear of the area at night.
Most of the protesters had left Florissant Avenue before midnight on Monday. Peacekeepers ushered people out of the middle of the street.
“Go home,” one woman peacekeeper said. “We can fight tomorrow.”

Title: Ferguson: Peaceful Night Derailed as Protesters Throw Bottles; 47 Arrested
Author: Mashable Team
ArticleText:
Mashable is following the latest from Ferguson, where protesters and police are squaring off over the killing of 18-year-old {Michael Brown}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/11/brown-shooting-ferguson-protests/#F0bloT_2RPqG”>. See Monday's live coverage {here}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/18/ferguson-live-updates/#N3ozbhLfPaqc”>.
3 things you need to know on Tuesday, Aug. 19:
  Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon calls for "vigorous prosecution" in Michael Brown's death.
  St. Louis County police said they arrested 47 people overnight, seized three guns.
  U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder sends message to Ferguson; grand jury to convene Wednesday.
REPORTERS IN FERGUSON, Mo.: Amanda Wills ({@amandawills}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/amandawills”>), Ashley Codianni ({@AshleyCodianni}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/AshleyCodianni”>) | EDITORS IN NEW YORK, SAN FRANCISCO, TORONTO, AUSTRALIA: Brian Ries ({@moneyries}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/moneyries”>), Jonathan Ellis ({@jonathanellis}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/jonathanellis”>), Kate Sommers-Dawes ({@ekatesd}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/ekatesd”>), Anita Li ({@neeeda}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/neeeda”>) , Jenni Ryall ({@jennijenni}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/jennijenni”>)
We're winding down the live blog, and will return later this morning. Stay with us for more updates on Ferguson then. – JR
Police hold press conference in Ferguson: 47 people arrested
3:15 a.m. ET: As a night of peaceful protests once again ended in disarray, 47 people were arrested overnight between 8 p.m. and 1:30 a.m. in Ferguson, Capt. Ron Johnson of the Missouri Highway Patrol said in a press conference early Wednesday morning. It was in comparison to 31 arrests in the same time period yesterday.
Ferguson was calm overnight until just before midnight when protesters began throwing glass and plastic bottles at police officers, Johnson said.
[tweetbegin 501991558141726720 tweetend]
The police did not use smoke bombs or tear gas this time, though some officers did use pepper spray, Johnson said. Again, no bullets were fired by the police.
Johnson gave credit to a group of volunteers, clergy and activists who came out to urge peace and influence younger protesters. "I believe there was a turning point tonight," Johnson said.
Two loaded guns were seized from a vehicle that was identified as a threat to police at 8:30 p.m. Another loaded gun was retrieved from a different incident. - JR
[tweetbegin 501987598559367168 tweetend]
At least 10 people reportedly detained outside of McDonald's restaurant
1:45 a.m. ET: Tensions were running high in the parking lot of a 24-hour McDonald's restaurant on W. Florissant Avenue, with 10 people reportedly detained.
Vice News confirmed a legal observer from the National Lawyer's Guild was arrested during the scuffle. The observer was wearing an official's bright green cap.
{Local news station KMOV}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/KMOV”> reported the chaos was caused by protesters throwing objects at police. The confrontation came after an injured protester had been loaded into an ambulance, as the crowd screamed "she's pregnant."
Media were asked to leave to area by authorities and move on to a briefing area outside Target. They were then asked to move down another street. A press conference is expected this morning, but a time has not been confirmed. - JR
[tweetbegin 501968403259613185 tweetend]
Peaceful protests derailed after water bottles thrown; at least 1 arrest reportedly made
1 a.m. ET: Tensions in Ferguson escalated just before 1 a.m. ET, derailing the evening's mostly peaceful protests, after water bottles were thrown. At least one arrest was reportedly made.Police formed a line, and began chasing a group running north on W. Florissant, after water bottles were thrown. An officer spoke through a bullhorn, telling protesters to stop throwing objects and "disperse immediately."
[tweetbegin 501957769965338624 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501962337751158785 tweetend]
"If you are in the middle of the street, you are unlawfully assembled," he said. Police also told reporters to move to the media area. 
[tweetbegin 501957916271083520 tweetend]
The scene became chaotic shortly after, with Vice's Tim Pool reporting that one person was arrested. Pool also said that he "heard a pop," but could not confirm that the sound was of gunshots.
[tweetbegin 501962037376090112 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501955777473818624 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501960545533431809 tweetend]
To de-escalate tension, some protesters held hands, and formed a line between police officers and the crowd. Protesters in the crowd also chanted "Hands up, don't shoot," and moved backward on W. Florissant. – AL
Police, some protesters wary of heavy media presence in Ferguson
FERGUSON, Mo., 11:30 p.m. ET -- "We ready, we ready, we ready for y'all," the crowd sang in perfect unison as they walked down Florissant Ave. on Tuesday night.There are more people in Ferguson Tuesday night, and cops relocated the press area from the top of the hill at W. Florissant Avenue and Ferguson Avenue, to a darker corner in front of the now-dilapidated QT. While some protesters are still willing to speak to media, many of them are weary of the presence of journalists. And for good reason. Police have repeatedly threatened to arrest protesters if they don't keep moving, or step off the sidewalk and into the streets. The problem is the sheer amount of media, here -- I even spotted a team of young students wearing yellow shirts that said Missouri School of Journalism -- pushing protesters into the streets. Police shout, and protesters blame reporters clamoring for the perfect photo or headline quote.
[tweetbegin 501900620602023936 tweetend]
Police tonight are also focused on media. They have posted themselves near the press corral, partly for safety, but mostly for show of force (something we also saw first-hand on Monday night).
It's not to say that protesters are anti-media. In fact, some said they genuinely believe things would be worse in Ferguson if the world's attention wasn't on the city. "We need you here," said Chrystal Williams, 41. "Everyone needs to see this." – AW[tweetbegin 501939039810113536 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501908875671789569 tweetend]
Missouri Governor calls for 'vigorous prosecution' in Michael Brown's death
10:15 p.m. ET: In a video statement released Tuesday night, Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon said "vigorous prosecution must now be pursued" in Michael Brown's death, prompting some to criticize him for what they perceived to be biased language.
[tweetbegin 501907210595614723 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501907386672496640 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501908296291590144 tweetend]
For more details, read the full post, {here}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/19/jay-nixon-vigorous-prosecution-michael-brown/#sPDHpfmh4iqp”>. – AL
St. Louis County PD: 52 people were arrested from Monday through Tuesday overnight
9:45 p.m. ET: St. Louis County police arrested 52 people from Monday through Tuesday overnight, the department confirmed late Tuesday.The arrests were made between 8 a.m. Monday to 8 a.m. Tuesday, local time. People from Missouri made up 38 arrests, including four from Ferguson, while 14 were from outside of Missouri. Here is the exact breakdown: Missouri:Florissant - 7Ferguson - 4Jennings - 2Flordell Hills - 1Creve Coeur - 1Hazelwood - 1Bel-Ridge - 1City of St. Louis - 15Unincorporated St. Louis County - 6Outside of Missouri:Washington, D.C. - 1Illinois - 4Maryland - 1California - 1Virginia - 1New York - 4Alabama - 1Texas - 1Of those arrested, 93% were not Ferguson residents, while 27% were not Missouri residents, the police department said. However, many people arrested were from towns in the St. Louis area. The majority of the arrests were for "refusal to disperse." One arrest was made for "possession of controlled substance," two for "warrants/failure to appear" and one for "interfering with a law enforcement officer." - AL
Sundown: Armored trucks roll in
9 p.m. ET -- The sun is setting on Ferguson and, reportedly earlier than in nights past, armored police trucks are rolling in.
[tweetbegin 501892747918581761 tweetend]
Though images from the scene still depict a calm event with pretty of kids present, the trucks are setting up in parking lots around the area, to the dismay of protesters gathered there.
[tweetbegin 501893132045516800 tweetend]
The sight of heavily armored officers, trucks, and the barking of police dogs has typically had the effect of escalating violence at the protests, rather than disarming it. It has been the point at which peaceful protests transform into a clash between police, media, those there to cause trouble, and the citizen peacekeepers who remain in the fray to try and keep it calm.
It's beginning to appear as if tonight may be no different. – KSD
Demonstrations resume in Ferguson
8 p.m. ET -- Community members have resumed marching on Florissant Ave. in Ferguson, as they have nightly since Michael Brown was shot.
Some, including Twitter co-founder and St. Louis native Jack Dorsey, are once again handing out roses in memory of the teen. There have been reports of security checkpoints at either end of the street, which police apparently closed to traffic for about two miles.
[tweetbegin 501866614284091392 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501876595322519553 tweetend]
Crowds continued to gather at Riverview Blvd. and McLaran Ave. in north St. Louis, where a 23-year-old man was shot by police earlier today. That's about 2.5 miles from the protests in Ferguson.
The familiar "don't shoot" refrain had been adjusted by some to an angrier "Hands up, shoot back," in light of the latest officer-involved shooting in the area.
That and the dual demonstrations left many wondering what would happen as violence bubbles up after dark. – KSD
Protesters demand murder charge for Officer Darren Wilson
CLAYTON, Missouri, 6:30 p.m. ET -- The Ferguson protests stretched beyond Florissant Ave. today when a group of around 100 demonstrators gathered in front of the office Bob McCulloch, St. Louis county prosecuting attorney.
Protesters are pushing for McCulloch to charge Darren Wilson, who shot and killed Michael Brown, with murder. Wilson is currently on paid leave.
Holding signs with slogans like "Justice for Mike Brown" while chanting in unison, the group, which was made up of both white and black protesters, stood face to face with one lightly armed guard in a white shirt. Behind him, a row of nearly 20 police officers wearing bulletproof vests gathered. One cop even filmed the protest with a handheld camera.
Asked what would happen if protesters tried to enter the building, a police officer with the last name Barton told Mashable all of them would be arrested. Another cop who was standing by noted, "Looks pretty peaceful to me."
Clayton is an upper-class, predominately white neighborhood of St. Louis. McCulloch, whose father was a police offer shot by a black man while on duty in 1964, has been accused of racism. There have also since been concerns about the way his office has released information about the case and the way it has handled prior officer-involved shootings.
"The county police and Bob McCulloch have exacerbated the situation," said protester Elizabeth Vega. "And if you are not angry and enraged, then you are not paying attention."
This group of protesters was highly organized and well spoken. They also knew their boundaries. When two people were arrested, it was by choice -- essentially asking to be taken away in order to make a statement.
As the cops handcuffed the two protesters -- one man and one woman -- the crowd chanted: "This is what democracy looks like."
Minutes later, the protesters calmly put down their signs and made their way to their cars in the adjacent lot, many of them saying goodbye for just a few hours.
They'll see each other tonight on Florissant Ave. - AW
Eric Holder's message to Ferguson
6 p.m. ET -- U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder, who will be in Ferguson starting Tuesday to aid the federal investigation into Michael Brown's death, has written a letter to the beleaguered community in the {St. Louis Post-Dispatch}<hyperlink=”http://www.stltoday.com/news/opinion/a-message-to-the-people-of-ferguson/article_ea8b7358-67a3-5187-af8c-169567f27a0d.html”>.
In it, he shares details of the federal civil rights investigation currently underway by some 40 FBI agents and experienced prosecutors. "Hundreds of people have already been interviewed in connection with this matter," he writes, appearing to reassure protesters that justice is in the process of being sought. He also notes that a federal medical examiner conducted an autopsy of Brown's body. That was independent of two other autopsies: one by the county examiner and one requested by Brown's family.
Holder goes on to recognize the legitimacy of those who have been "peacefully exercising their First Amendment rights" but notes that acts of violence, even by a minority, "undermine, rather than advance, the cause of justice."
Above all, he says, the Justice Department's "investigation into this matter will be full, it will be fair, and it will be independent."
As for the local investigation into the shooting, the Post-Dispatch reports that the county's standing grand jury will begin hearing evidence in the investigation beginning Wednesday, "depending upon the ability to get the witnesses in and the witnesses showing up," according to a spokesman for St. Louis County Prosecutor Robert McCulloch.
[tweetbegin 501847451285073920 tweetend]
Speaking on an unrelated matter, SLPD Chief Sam Dotson told local outlet KPLR that Tuesday's officer-involved shooting of a 23-year-old man was an "isolated incident" that is unrelated to the events in Ferguson.
[tweetbegin 501846799918063617 tweetend]
It is, however, still serving to fuel tensions in the St. Louis area. – KSD
Michael Brown's funeral scheduled for Monday
3:30 p.m. ET: Brown's funeral and memorial service will be on Monday. "More information will follow in a media alert once arrangements are finalized," Brown family attorney {said}<hyperlink=”http://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/michael-brown-funeral-monday”> in announcing the news in an email to reporters.
[tweetbegin 501804795263713282 tweetend]
Officer-involved shooting leaves man dead in north St. Louis
2:30 p.m. ET: A man was {shot dead}<hyperlink=”http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/st-louis-police-investigating-fatal-officer-involved-shooting/article_85d27316-a17a-5e0a-b1d6-8a6753e2fcb2.html”> after reportedly brandishing a knife at St. Louis city police officers, {local media say}<hyperlink=”http://fox2now.com/2014/08/19/officer-involved-shooting-in-north-st-louis-2/”>.
Fox 2 reports the man walked into a market at Mclaren and Riverview and got into a confrontation with the owner. Police were called, and the suspect refused to put down the weapon. He was reportedly shot after trying to attack police, Fox 2 {said}<hyperlink=”http://fox2now.com/2014/08/19/officer-involved-shooting-in-north-st-louis-2/”>. The location is about {four miles from Ferguson}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/RobertDEdwards/status/501799456191578112”>.
St. Louis City Police Chief Sam Dotson confirmed on Twitter that a fatal shooting had occurred, adding that the investigation was ongoing.
[tweetbegin 501796619097239552 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501808198916263936 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501808398531563522 tweetend]
Speaking to reporters shortly after the shooting, Chief Dotson said the suspect, a 23-year-old black man who was acting "erratically," lunged at the officers with a knife, telling police, "shoot me now, kill me now" from a distance of approximately three to four feet. After the suspect refused to drop the knife, officers fired.
"Officer safety is the number one issue," the police chief said, defending the shooting. "Every police officer that's out here has a right to defend themselves."
[tweetbegin 501807453684912130 tweetend]
He said he didn't yet know if the store had surveillance footage of the incident, and asked witnesses to step forward, adding he hoped to get information about the shooting to the public as "truthfully and quickly as possible." He said he is investigating how many shots were fired.
Tensions are high in the city after Michael Brown, 18, was fatally wounded by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson on Aug. 9.
[tweetbegin 501798169865625600 tweetend]
A crowd immediately began to gather at the crime scene in St. Louis on Tuesday afternoon. Their mood, a KMOX reporter {tweeted}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/brettblumekmox/status/501801845434900480”>, was turning ugly. Some began chanting, "Hands up, don't shoot!"
There was, an NBC News reporter tweeted, a "heavy police presence" at the scene.
[tweetbegin 501795682177798144 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501796248085876737 tweetend]
Darren Wilson texts his friend about this 'stressful time,' report says
2 p.m. ET: According to a {report}<hyperlink=”http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2729021/I-t-support-really-keeping-going-stressful-time-Just-stay-safe-Under-24-hour-guard-fear-life-Darren-Wilson-breaks-silence-texts-friend.html”> in MailOnline, Darren Wilson — the police officer who fatally shot unarmed teenager Michael Brown — texted a friend from an unknown location to thank him for appearing on CNN on his behalf.
[tweetbegin 501787866926968832 tweetend]
The friend, Jake Shepard, has also appeared on CNN to vouch for his friend Wilson.
According to Shepard, Wilson has told him that he can't leave protective custody because he and his child could be targeted. -BR
City to residents: Stay home at night
1:30 p.m. ET: The city of Ferguson asked its residents to "stay home at night," following another round of protests and arrests that have crippled the St. Louis suburb since the shooting of an unarmed teenager Aug. 9.
"It is our hope that as we continue to work for the well-being of Ferguson, residents will stay home at night, allow peace to settle in, and allow for the justice process to take its course," the city said in a statement, according to the {St. Louis Post-Dispatch}<hyperlink=”http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/ferguson-calls-for-nighttime-quiet-and-reconciliation-pledges-dash-and/article_375eff87-6a6b-534b-abcc-a8664e7d3ba2.html”>. "We owe it to our children to be able to return to school and work together peacefully for Ferguson’s future."
The city also reportedly promised it would begin to seek funds to buy dashboard and body cameras for its police force. In a {list}<hyperlink=”http://www.thewire.com/national/2014/08/city-of-ferguson-pledges-to-foster-diverse-police-force-and-vest-cameras/378778/”> of actions the city said it was "exploring," was a "commitment to raise funds and secure dash and vest cams for our patrol cars." – BR
List of journalists arrested while covering protests grows
1 p.m. ET: The number of journalists arrested while covering the protests in Ferguson {grew to 11 overnight}<hyperlink=”http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/19/us/ferguson-journalists-arrested/”>, with reports that The Intercept's Ryan Devereaux, Getty Images photographer Scott Olson and Kerry Picket, a reporter with Breitbart News, joined the club.
[tweetbegin 501762891893473280 tweetend]
Poynter, a journalism institute, is keeping a {running tally}<hyperlink=”http://www.poynter.org/2014/which-journalists-have-been-arrested-in-ferguson/264273/”>.
[tweetbegin 501737792435912704 tweetend]
The American Society of News Editors called the arrests and media restrictions in Ferguson part of a "concerted, top-down effort to restrict the fundamental First Amendment rights of the public and the press."
"From the beginning of this situation, the police have made conscious decisions to restrict information and images coming from Ferguson," ASNE President David Boardman said in a {statement}<hyperlink=”http://asne.org/blog_home.asp?Display=1743”> issued late last week. "Of course, these efforts largely have been unsuccessful, as the nation and the world are still seeing for themselves the heinous actions of the police. For every reporter they arrest, every image they block, every citizen they censor, another will still write, photograph and speak." – BR
78 arrested in Ferguson protests Monday night
12:30 p.m. ET: 78 people were arrested overnight, records show, representing a dramatic increase in the number of {previously known arrests}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/18/ferguson-live-updates/#N3ozbhLfPaqc”> Monday night.
Eighteen of the people arrested were from outside Missouri, NBC News {reported}<hyperlink=”http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/michael-brown-shooting/78-arrested-overnight-most-missouri-arrest-records-show-n184036”>. In an overnight news conference, Capt. Ron Johnson of the Missouri Highway Patrol made a point of noting that some were from as far away as New York and California.
"These are not acts of protests, but acts of violent criminals," Johnson said.
[tweetbegin 501767499801559040 tweetend]
Johnson had said overnight that 31 people had been arrested. The majority of them were booked for refusing to disperse -- only two were arrested for {unlawful use of a weapon}<hyperlink=”http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/michael-brown-shooting/78-arrested-overnight-most-missouri-arrest-records-show-n184036”>. - BR

Title: Hours Before Curfew, Protestors Clash with Police in Ferguson
Author: Adario Strange08/17/2014
ArticleText:
In the hours leading up to the midnight curfew in Ferguson, Mo., police in riot gear and military equipment fired tear gas and smoke projectiles into a large crowd of protesters, still angered over the killing of teenager Michael Brown by a local police officer.
Interrupting what had been a mostly calm day of protester activity and church serices, tensions in the area began to rise around 8:30 p.m. local time as bystanders milled in the streets as police looked on, according to various reports from people on the ground in Ferguson reporting via social media.
Around that time, the St. Louis Police Department sent out a Twitter message reporting that shots had been fired, and shortly thereafter confirmed that there was at least one shooting victim.
[tweetbegin 501179623275642880 tweetend]
Not long after those messages, the same police Twitter feed reported that Molotov cocktails had been thrown. Additional reports from bystanders broadcast on NBC News indicated that some were also throwing rocks at the police.
[tweetbegin 501189523091361792 tweetend]
And at about the same time, someone threw stones through the plate-glass windows of the local McDonalds on West Florissant Street, near the epicenter of the past week of protests.
Soon after, police fired tear gas into crowd. Video feeds showed the police, equipped in riot gear, advancing on the crowd. An 8-year-old boy was reportedly hit by tear gas.
[tweetbegin 501193280948682752 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501193632595337218 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501192812566937600 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501193714614931457 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 501191862431272960 tweetend]
UPDATE, Aug. 17, 10:53 p.m. ET: Nearly an hour after the first reports of shots fired, the St. Louis Police Department reported that additional shots had been fired. 
[tweetbegin 501197914606014464 tweetend]
Additional reports from bystanders revealed that the local McDonald's had been looted.
They just looted the McDonalds by me! {#Ferguson}<hyperlink=” https://twitter.com/hashtag/Ferguson?src=hash”> {pic.twitter.com/wg6H1nTA1Y}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/account/suspended”>
— The Tech CEO (@TheTechCEO) {August 18, 2014}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/account/suspended”>
UPDATE, Aug. 18, 1:18 a.m. ET: Roughly 15 minutes after the start of the curfew, with unconfirmed reports of gunfire in several locations and a small number of people still on the streets, the St. Louis Police Department reportedly announced plans to hold a press briefing.
A {live stream}<hyperlink=”http://livestream.com/accounts/9035483/events/3271930”> of the press conference is being provided by the "I am Mike Brown Live" video stream from 
[tweetbegin 501234385635799040 tweetend]
UPDATE, Aug. 18, 2:22 a.m. ET: As promised, Missouri Highway Patrol Capt. Ron Johnson addressed the press at around 1:15 a.m. local time.
Describing the situation leading up to the use of tear gas on the protesters, Capt. Johnson laid out a timeline of the evening's events.
"There were shootings, looting and other acts of violence that clearly appear not to have been spontaneous, but premeditated," said Capt. Johnson.
Calling the actions by some of the people on the streets "preplanned agitation," Capt. Johnson said, "we had to act to protect lives and property."
According to Capt. Johnson, the timeline leading to the use of tear gas was as follows:
8:25 p.m.: A shooting occurred in the area. Soon after, shots were fired at officers, and Molotov cocktails were also thrown at officers.
8:26 p.m.: More shots fired (no details on the circumstances).
8:27 p.m.: Report of a subject down from gunfire.
8:28 p.m.: Report of eight people seen with guns. Tactical team dispatched.
9:20 p.m.: McDonald's overrun and employees locked themselves in the storage room.
"Based on these conditions," said Capt. Johnson, "I had no alternative but to elevate our response." Capt. Johnson also confirmed that no officers had been injured.
After taking a few questions, Capt. Johnson abruptly ended the press conference.
Governor Jay Nixon has also issued {an executive order}<hyperlink=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/following-coordinated-attacks-civilians-and-law-enforcement-governor-nixon-signs”> to bring the National Guard to Ferguson to deal with the situation.
"I am directing the highly capable men and women of the Missouri National Guard to assist Colonel Ron Replogle and the Unified Command in restoring peace and order to this community," said Nixon in a statement on his website.
As of this writing, the situation in Ferguson, Mo. appears to be calm. However, in the wake of {new revelations}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/17/michael-brown-autopsy-shot-six-times/#RNn2V9b2M8qb”> contained in Michael Brown's autopsy report revealed on Sunday, as well as the use of tear gas on protesters and news that the National Guard is headed to the area, authorities may find it difficult to maintain the current state of calm when protesters return to the streets on Monday.

Title: 'Da Man Wit the Chips' in Iconic Ferguson Photo Identified
Author: Brian Ries
ArticleText:
He's an American legend. A hero. The G.O.A.T. (Greatest Of All Time). The MVP (Most Valuable Protester).
The image of the dread-locked man {throwing a tear gas canister}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/manofsteele/status/499432557906104320”> while wearing an American flag T-shirt and holding a bag of Red Hot Riplets — a kind of spicy, barbecue-flavored potato chips — has become the photo of the Ferguson protests.
But the man with the chips, who was photographed during protests in Ferguson on Wednesday night, wants you to know he wasn't throwing it at police. He was throwing it away.
"I don't think 'da man wit the chips' was throwing it back at police. I think he was throwing it away from him and kids he was standing near," {said the man}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/eyeFLOODpanties/status/500136421676417025”>, who goes by the Twitter name @eyeFLOODpanties.

Title: State Police Take Charge in Ferguson; Governor Compares City to a 'War Zone'
Author: Mashable Team
ArticleText:
The unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, {took a dramatic turn}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/14/ferguson-violence-arrests/#_V5uN6PuMOqM”> on Wednesday night.Mashable provided live updates of the aftermath on Thursday. Our coverage is below.
3 things you need to know now:
The unrest started on Sunday after a police officer shot and killed 18-year-old {Michael Brown}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/11/brown-shooting-ferguson-protests/#7hZ8KLk8DPqQ”> , who was unarmed.
Ferguson police, who are heavily armed and {excessively militarized}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/13/ferguson-police-protests-vs-iraq/#oOljCHcj2gql”>, used tear gas and rubber bullets against demonstrators and arrested journalists on Wednesday night.
Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon has, in turn, handed over law enforcement to state highway patrol.
Missouri State Highway Patrol takes over security
4:15 p.m. ET: Missouri State Highway Patrol will take over security in Ferguson, Gov. Jay Nixon announced Thursday afternoon.
"Law enforcement in Ferguson will be turned over to state highway patrol," Gov. Nixon announced to a room full of reporters. Nixon said Ferguson "looked a little bit more like a war zone, and it's not acceptable."
[tweetbegin 500012937965502464 tweetend] 
[tweetbegin 500013452795314176 tweetend]
When asked who was calling the shots Wednesday night, Gov. Nixon wouldn't answer. "That was yesterday," he said. "I'm not looking backward. I'm looking forward."
The plan, starting Thursday night, was developed to allow "more movement, trying to bring in a different tone of the amplitude of protective force," he said, referring to the "operational shift" he expects to provide both parties — protesters and police — to step back and take a breather.
All in all, the unrest in Ferguson feels like an "old wound," the governor saids.
The challenges Ferguson faces "go much more deep," he said. The key, he added, is to get control, let voices be heard, protect property, open up and "be a little bit more free." However, Nixon said there are other problems that will need to be addressed.
"These are deep and existing problems not only in Missouri, but in America, but this has clearly touched a nerve," he said.
"While we're focused today on the shorter operational things, I think ultimately we will be gauged as to whether or not this was an opportunity used to begin to make some longer term healing, and understanding," the governor said.
"We'll do our best to reestablish the rule of law and subsequently expand the trust."
Eric Holder concerned about deployment of military equipment's message
3 p.m. ET: Attorney General Eric Holder {issued a statement}<hyperlink=”http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/statement-attorney-general-eric-holder-latest-developments-ferguson-missouri”> Thursday afternoon saying he was "deeply concerned" about the conflicting message that the deployment of military equipment and vehicles sends.
“At a time when we must seek to rebuild trust between law enforcement and the local community, I am deeply concerned that the deployment of military equipment and vehicles sends a conflicting message," Holder said. "At my direction, Department officials have conveyed these concerns to local authorities. Also at my direction, the Department is offering – through our COPS office and Office of Justice Programs – technical assistance to local authorities in order to help conduct crowd control and maintain public safety without relying on unnecessarily extreme displays of force. The local authorities in Missouri have accepted this offer of assistance as of this afternoon."
In the same statement, Holder also toed a similar line as President Obama did earlier, condemning violence by members of the public while calling on law enforcement to "seek to reduce tensions, not heighten them."
“For one thing, while the vast majority of protests have been peaceful, acts of violence by members of the public cannot be condoned. Looting and willful efforts to antagonize law enforcement officers who are genuinely trying to protect the public do nothing to remember the young man who has died. Such conduct is unacceptable and must be unequivocally condemned.“By the same token, the law enforcement response to these demonstrations must seek to reduce tensions, not heighten them. Those who peacefully gather to express sympathy for the family of Michael Brown must have their rights respected at all times. And journalists must not be harassed or prevented from covering a story that needs to be told.
See the full statement on the {DOJ's website}<hyperlink=”http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/statement-attorney-general-eric-holder-latest-developments-ferguson-missouri”>.
Ferguson police chief: We are changing our tactics
1:51 p.m. ET: Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson struck a new tone Thursday morning, saying he'd allow people to "freely protest" — as long as they stayed on sidewalks.
"[We will be] changing our tactics," Chief Jackson told members of the media after what he said was a productive meeting with the NAACP and the Department of Justice.
However, Jackson defended his department's militarized response, saying tactical commanders on the ground were responding to "deadly force" used by protesters who threw Molotov cocktails, rocks, bricks and bottles.
"I understand it doesn't look good, but there is gunfire. There are firebombs being thrown at police," the chief said. "We want this to be peaceful."
The chief said protesters will be encouraged to stay on the sidewalks — not by barricades, but by "cones" instead — and may use porta-potties the department will set up on their behalf.
[tweetbegin 499975665903763456 tweetend]
"We're going to give sidewalks to the protesters and allow them to freely protest for as long as they want," he said. 
[tweetbegin 499972306014597120 tweetend]
After he spoke, Missouri Senator Claire McCaskill, a former prosecutor, took the microphone and said Wednesday night's police presence escalated the situation in Ferguson as "this kind of response by police has become more of the problem instead of the solution."
"My goal has been demilitarize the situation," McCaskill said, adding she's spoken with Attorney General Eric Holder about the police's enhanced weaponry.
"I think the demilitarization of the response is going to help a lot," she said.
[tweetbegin 499972000878985216 tweetend]
Obama: Police shouldn't arrest journalists there who are "just doing their jobs"
1:03 p.m. ET: President Obama took a break from his vacation in Martha's Vineyard on Thursday to {address}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/14/ferguson-obama-police/#zAbCjDnCMSqL”> the "violent turn" of events in Ferguson. He had been briefed on the situation by Attorney Gen. Eric Holder, Obama said, whose department has now been tasked with coordinating with local authorities.
"I know that many Americans have been deeply disturbed by the images that we’ve seen in the heartland of our country," the president said.
Obama said he'd spoken to Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, a "good man and a fine governor," and expressed his concern over the "violent turn that events have taken on the ground."
[tweetbegin 499964581297815552 tweetend]
Obama then called the death of Michael Brown "heartbreaking and tragic," and said the local authorities needed to be open and transparent about their investigation.
The president then spoke about the friction that's arose between police and protesters over the past four days, saying "there is never an excuse for violence against police." However, Obama said, "there's no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests."
President Obama said he's tasked the Department of Justice and the FBI with investigating the death of Michael Brown. He also reiterated several times that demonstrators there have a right to peaceful protests.
"There is no excuse for police to use force against peaceful protesters," Obama said. He added that police in Ferguson should not bully or arrest journalists there who are "just doing their jobs."
Governor is making operational shifts in Ferguson
12:51 p.m. ET: Missouri Governor Jay Nixon told a group of clergy members that his team was "working through a number of operational things to make some shifts," and hinted to the Ferguson community they would "see a different tone" as a result.
The governor, who drew applause from the Clergy Coalition crowd in St. Louis, apologized for being late — he was talking on the phone with President Obama.
Gov. Nixon also called for press freedoms following a night that saw at least two reporters arrested in Ferguson and a TV crew with Al-Jazeera America hit with tear gas.
"If the media wants to take pictures of things and cover stuff they ought to do it, we live in a free country," he said.
[tweetbegin 499964581297815552 tweetend]
Nixon is expected to announce those changes later this afternoon.
Senator calls for demilitarization of police
12:35 p.m. ET: Missouri Senator Claire McCaskill spoke on Thursday at a meeting for clergy members and called for a demilitarization of the situation no the ground.
"We need to de-militarize this situation — this kind of response by the police has become the problem instead of the solution. I obviously respect law enforcement's work to provide public safety, but my constituents are allowed to have peaceful protests, and the police need to respect that right and protect that right. Today is going to be a new start, we can and need to do better," she said.
[tweetbegin 499948996811837440 tweetend]
Missouri governor: Ferguson does not represent who we are as Americans
11:30 a.m. ET: Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon, who is now headed to the St. Louis suburb, issued a statement Thursday morning acknowledging that local authorities in Ferguson have violated the rights of both protesters and the press.
"The worsening situation in Ferguson is deeply troubling, and does not represent who we are as Missourians or as Americans," Nixon, a Democrat, said.
"While we all respect the solemn responsibility of our law enforcement officers to protect the public, we must also safeguard the rights of Missourians to peaceably assemble and the rights of the press to report on matters of public concern."
For days, journalists have been on the ground in Ferguson, documenting police tactics. But they had trouble getting the story even before Wednesday night. Police have repeatedly told reporters to get out of the way, and the FAA on Wednesday {granted a request to ban flights}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/12/faa-flights-media-ferguson-missouri/#k43QSE7QDkq3”> over the area, including news helicopters.
Ferguson authorities said the restriction was for safety. Journalists said it was an attempt to black out media coverage.
Civilians in Ferguson have been clashing with police off and on since Sunday, shortly after the death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old unarmed black teenager who was shot and killed by a police officer. They've chanted "hands up, don't shoot" as police, who are outfitted in riot gear and armed to the teeth, have trained their weapons on them.
But things took a dramatic turn on Wednesday evening as the unrest turned increasingly chaotic.
Around 10 p.m. local time, police fired smoke grenades and rubber bullets into a crowd of hundreds after a protester threw a Molotov cocktail. St. Louis County police then ordered protesters and journalists — who have been flooding the Internet with photos and first-person accounts of the excessive militarization of the police — to turn off their cameras.
The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that about 10 people had been arrested, including St. Louis Alderman Antonio French, who has been chronicling the protests on social media. Local authorities also arrested two journalists: Washington Post's Wesley Lowery and Huffington Post's Ryan Reilly, both of whom have been steadfast in tweeting and have become two highly sourced reporters covering this story.

Title: This Person Live-Tweeted Michael Brown's Killing
Author: Brian Reis
ArticleText:
Just after 12 p.m. local time in Ferguson, Missouri, a suburb of St. Louis, a Twitter user and St. Louis-area rapper named Thee Pharoah tweeted that he saw someone die.
[tweetbegin 498152572062945281 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498152622012907520 tweetend]
He offered a friend a little more detail.
[tweetbegin 498152874312867840 tweetend]
He then tweeted a photo of Michael Brown's dead body lying in the street (warning: this is graphic).
[tweetbegin 498152994014130176 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498153293583884288 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498155002305581056 tweetend]
When asked why be another user on Twitter, Thee Pharoah said there was no reason.
[tweetbegin 498155311153180672 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498155651617411072 tweetend]
The world would {later learn}<hyperlink=”http://mashable.com/2014/08/15/ferguson-police-name-michael-brown-officer/#soyVuEcHEZqH”> that Michael Brown was shot after the officer, Darren Wilson, encountered him and another man on the street at 12:01 p.m. local time. The initial confrontation occurred because Brown and a friend were "walking down the street blocking traffic," Ferguson's police chief said on Friday.
[tweetbegin 498155867208822784 tweetend]
Eyewitness to the shooting who have previously spoken to the media {said}<hyperlink=”http://fox2now.com/2014/08/14/witnesses-to-michael-browns-shooting-detail-his-last-minutes/”> Brown ran before he was shot. Thee Pharoah said the same in his tweets.
[tweetbegin 498157636395614208 tweetend]
The Twitter user said he saw Brown, who looked to be 18 or 19, get hit with at least seven shots.
[tweetbegin 498166774865465344 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498166843933077505 tweetend]
Two of those shots, the Twitter witness says, were from behind. The other five came it a "barrage" after Brown turned around.
[tweetbegin 498167134367645696 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 498170566449172480 tweetend]
The police then descended on the area. Thee Pharoah posted this photo of an officer with a rifle. There's no indication that this officer was involved in the shooting.
[tweetbegin 498185574713290752 tweetend]
And yet Brown's body remained on the ground, at least two hours after the unarmed teen was shot dead.
[tweetbegin 498191022489231360 tweetend]
On Sunday, Thee Pharoah thanked his friends for checking on him, and then on Wednesday, he tweeted he was finished tweeting about what he had witnessed.
[tweetbegin 498673776867803136 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 499456050647400448 tweetend]
Since the tweets, numerous Twitter users have told Thee Pharoah to keep his head down and lay low. He's been told to "lawyer up" and not speak to the media.
[tweetbegin 499457584122691584 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 499454163806195712 tweetend]
The Twitter user didn't respond to Mashable's requests for comment, both over Twitter and email. These tweets were initially {found by Tim Dickinson}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/7im/timelines/499639344613695488”>, who covers news for Rolling Stone, and were not independently verified by Mashable, though they appear to be authentic.
Notes: There was a tweet that was improperly embedded, and was not clickable.  It is a tweet by @WillieSlater, at the end of the article.

Title: Arrest Won't Stop Photographer Scott Olson in Ferguson
Author: Dustin Drankoski
ArticleText:
In the days since protests broke out in Ferguson, Missouri, following the death of unarmed teenager Michael Brown, the photos from the scene have been striking, with the police there {eerily resembling}<hyperlink=” http://mashable.com/2014/08/13/ferguson-police-protests-vs-iraq/#NDGeU0tzvgqK”> a military operation.
Getty photographer Scott Olson has been on the ground since Aug. 11. On Monday, Olson was arrested while covering the protests, but released later in the day. "I want to be able to do my job as a member of the media and not be arrested for just doing my job," he told Pancho Bernasconi, vice president of news at Getty Images.
The arrest didn't deter him. He captured {another violent night}<hyperlink=” http://mashable.com/2014/08/18/ferguson-live-updates/#4acACxyZEaqA”> between the police and protestors when two were shot and 31 were arrested.

Title: SWAT Teams Fire Tear Gas, Flash Grenades on Ferguson Protesters
Author: Kate Sommers-Dawes
ArticleText:
Heavily-armed SWAT officers fired on protesters after arresting and reportedly assaulting two national reporters in Ferguson, Missouri, Wednesday night.

Ryan J. That quickly brought national attention to local police officers' actions, as the situation in Ferguson deteriorated.

Reilly and Lowery said they were working in a McDonald's when officers entered and ordered everyone to leave. Reilly told MSNBC that the officers said they were "shutting down" the restaurant, and when Reilly didn't pack fast enough, he was arrested and detained for what seemed to be about an hour.

“I knew I was going to be fine,” he said. “But the thing is, so many people here in Ferguson don’t have as many Twitter followers as I have and don’t have Jeff Bezos or whoever to call and bail them out of jail.”
Wednesday's protests began in daylight hours, in accordance with police directives. Based on {live streams}<hyperlink=”http://www.ustream.tv/RealAlexJones”> that showed them in real-time, the protests were largely calm, though they quickly escalated as night fell.
Demonstrators' chants of "No peace, no justice" and "Police: We are all Michael Brown" turned into "F*ck the police," as authorities began firing tear gas, rubber bullets and flash grenades into the crowd. That was apparently in response to a thrown bottle or other projectiles. St. Louis County Police told Matt Sczesny of local news station KMOV that at least {10 arrests}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/KMOVMatt/status/499766320100311040”> were made in Ferguson. The St. Louis County Police also {confirmed to local news station KSDK}<hyperlink=”https://twitter.com/CaseyNolen/status/499767555674763265”> early Thursday morning that the department's email has been down for the past three hours, and that it is investigating a "potential hack."
Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon announced on Wednesday night via Twitter that he would be canceling a scheduled appearance at the Missouri State Fair to visit North St. Louis County, where Ferguson is located.
Around 1 A.M. ET, Gov. Nixon released a statement on the unrest that said, in part: "The worsening situation in Ferguson is deeply troubling, and does not represent who we are as Missourians or as Americans. While we all respect the solemn responsibility of our law enforcement officers to protect the public, we must also safeguard the rights of Missourians to peaceably assemble and the rights of the press to report on matters of public concern."
Nixon called on law enforcement to seek peace and allow journalists to continue to report.
"Once again, I ask that members of the community demonstrate patience and calm while the investigation continues, and I urge law enforcement agencies to keep the peace and respect the rights of residents and the press during this difficult time," the statement continued.
The Ferguson Police Department has been criticized for what has been seen as militant behavior, as it tries to keep the peace. Police had already used tear gas and rubber bullets before Wednesday on the outraged, grieving community in the days since Brown was killed. The department has also refused to release the name of the officer involved, citing security concerns, and full details of the event, due to the ongoing investigation, angering those affected.
There has been crime and acts of violence in the days following the shooting, which caused the police department to release an official statement urging residents to assemble "only during daylight hours in an organized and respectful manner."
The days following Brown's shooting have raised questions around the militarization of police in the U.S., thanks to a {Pentagon program}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/09/us/war-gear-flows-to-police-departments.html?_r=1”> that has transferred military equipment — including machine guns and armored vehicles — to local police departments.
